content: Ideally. The goal should be to have some back-and-forth with people to better understand their needs, pains, wants, desires, etc. to determine what specific outcome they want today that they currently don’t have (benefit). Once you’ve identified the benefit, then you want to throw some ideas around about what a solution might look like that would provide that benfit and see if they would be interested in such a thing. Any one of those two things can change your “guess” dramatically (or full out shut it down). So to code anything beforehand could wind up being a total waste of time. The biggest problem in building a SaaS isn’t writing code — people can usually pull that off. It’s almost always a marketing and sales problem. So I advocate that you market and sell before you write code because if you know you can write code but you don’t know if you can market or sell something, you should probably try to remove the unknown variable in that equation first. Hope this helps.
